entries.content: Use a pattern-interrupting opener on cold calls: 'Would you like to hang up or let me have 30 seconds?'
entries.notes: Designed to pique curiosity and gain explicit permission for a brief interaction.

entries.content: After a prospect says 'not interested', ask clarifying questions to understand their situation, like 'What typically keeps you busy or satisfied?'
entries.notes: Turns a brush-off into an opportunity to uncover underlying reasons or needs.

entries.content: Always ask for permission before delving into details or asking deeper questions: 'Would it be okay if I asked you just a couple of clarifying questions?'
entries.notes: Empowers the prospect and reduces resistance, earning the right to continue.

entries.content: The primary goal of the initial cold call opening is to gain permission to ask questions, not to make a pitch.
entries.notes: Focuses the early interaction on qualification and building rapport/trust.

entries.content: If a prospect interrupts or gives an early objection, revert to asking for permission to continue the conversation briefly.
entries.notes: Regains control politely and reinforces the permission-based approach.

entries.content: Maintain a confident, slightly playful, and non-desperate tone during initial prospect interactions.
entries.notes: Builds credibility and makes the salesperson more approachable and engaging.

entries.content: When asked to 'send information', qualify the prospect first by asking clarifying questions about their needs and interest.
entries.notes: Avoids sending generic information blindly; ensures relevance before investing time.
